file_content.text: Go on to Coruscant. Yuon needs you.
Yuon is resting comfortably, for now. It seems she's suffering some kind of illness.
I can't lie to you. Her condition is grave.
Is Master Yuon going to be alright?
Will she die?
Yuon thought sickness would take her.
We have some of the finest healers in the galaxy, can't we treat her?
Then let's help her.
Yuon tried to heal, Herald. Was no sickness she knew.
Master Yuon had been acting strangely....
I knew something was wrong.
She did best to hide sickness, Herald.
You knew Yuon was ill? And didn't inform us?
Is not for me to tell secrets. Was her wish to train one last hunter. I understood.
Now I see why she was so devoted to my training.
I was her last student?
We must act.
I thought you were friends. We could have helped her.
And now she's dying!
I gave oath, Herald.
We're sending Yuon to Coruscant. Our researchers there have been recovering artifacts from the first Jedi Temple; they may have something to cure Yuon.
Take a shuttle, and join Yuon on Coruscant. She will need your help.
I'll do everything I can to make her well.
I won't let her die.
I will do so.
More experienced Jedi should take care of her.
How can I be any help?
You are--were--her student. And you've proved how valuable your help can be.
Where Herald goes, I go also. Is Scorekeeper's wish.
Meantime, assure Yuon we will be studying your discoveries about Rajivari. Some of the claims his apprentices recorded... bear investigation.
When you reach Coruscant, go to our embassy in the Senate tower, and find a researcher called Attros Finn. He'll be expecting you.
Good luck. To you both. And may the Force be with you.
We've been waiting for you, Padawan. You've already met Master Jaric; this is Master Satele Shan.
I've been treating Nalen Raloch. The Pilgrims who carried him here told us of your battle. Remarkable.
I would have brought a peaceful solution if I could, Master.
I regret it came to violence.
Peace is the ideal, Padawan, but there's no shame in defending yourself.
How bad are his injuries, Master Satele? I wasn't sure he would survive.
Will Nalen live?
He will, though it will be a long recovery.
I always do good work.
You've begun well, Padawan. How you proceed remains to be seen.
Kalikori village sent word of the battle at the Forge, and Nalen Raloch's death. He could not be saved, then?
Nalen Raloch's reputation will survive. That will benefit Kalikori village more.
I saved his legacy.
I see you've thought this over.
Circumstances forced my hand.
You protected innocent lives. We cannot ask for more.
Nalen planned to destroy the Forge, then wage war against us. We're safer with him dead.
He was far too dangerous.
Clearly you believe that. But don't let the urgency of the moment blind you to other paths.
The deaths of the Pilgrims is problematic. It may take years to regain the village's trust--decades, even....
It seems we have much to learn about the villagers. Perhaps we should rethink our position....
Enough, enough. Padawan--the Fount of Rajivari. You actually set foot there? Please, tell me everything!
Master Rajivari himself spoke to me. What was left of him.
I met Rajivari.
You saw a Force apparition? Of Rajivari? This is extraordinary!
Its relics and technology have survived. Enough to keep our historians busy for years.
It's mostly intact.
You must record every detail for me--everything!
There was nothing to get excited over.
It was only a ruin.
Don't be ridiculous, it must have been a wonder! So much to see, to learn--
It seems you may have been right, Yuon. I... apologize. To you, and your Padawan.
No longer a Padawan. She carries a lightsaber; she has proven herself. I have only one last question before her training's complete.
No longer a Padawan. He carries a lightsaber; he has proven himself. I have only one last question before his training's complete.
At the moment, Nalen Raloch is resting in a kolto tank. When he's well, what should become of him?
Nalen proved he has great strength in the Force. Maybe he has a future with us.
Train him as a Jedi.
And bring reconciliation between us and the villagers--a sound idea.
Nalen fought and suffered for his village. If you judge it safe, let him go home.
Release him to his people.
Compassion. No Jedi should be without it.
Nalen is still a threat. He should remain in your custody, indefinitely.
Keep him prisoner.
Concern for the safety of others. Very prudent.
Nalen Raloch was corrupted and destroyed. You walked a similar path. Why did you not fall?
If I'd had an entire village to protect, Master Satele, perhaps I would have crossed some lines.
I didn't have Nalen's burdens.
Very honest. Always be mindful of your motives.
I had a Master who cared about my progress, and Qyzen as an ally. Nalen had no one.
Others helped me.
Yes. No Jedi can stand against darkness alone.
Nalen let himself be consumed by knowledge. I wouldn't allow such weakness.
I'm stronger than that.
Humility will be a hard-won lesson for you, I see. But, I'm satisfied.
We judge you ready to accept your place as a Jedi. Yuon, if you would?
Before this Council, I take from you the title of Padawan. I name you a full Jedi of our order. Honor the past. Work... for the future.
May the Force be always with you. You've... done so well, my student. I'm....
Master Yuon?
Come away. Yuon? Can you hear me?
Hello again, Padawan. I'm glad to see you well.
Master Syo Bakarn. I was there to greet you when you first arrived.
Being greeted by a member of the Council is hard to forget, Master Syo.
I remember.
Interesting. Protocol was never a big focus of Yuon's curriculum.
Do you need me for something, Master Syo?
What can I do for you?
At least she has a sense of responsibility.
At least he has a sense of responsibility.
I'm sorry. My work for Master Yuon has been keeping me preoccupied.
I don't remember you.
Yes. Yuon mentioned your "expeditions."
This is Master Jaric Kaedan, another of the Jedi Council. Yuon told us about Nalen Raloch, the Pilgrim seeking Rajivari's secrets.
She also claimed the Force is "guiding" your training. This isn't unknown, but....
So the Force influencing a Padawan's training is quite rare.
But it is unusual.
Yuon seems convinced. But trusting blindly in the Force isn't the Jedi way. Good judgment and discipline must temper that trust.
Master Yuon mentioned this, but she didn't go into details.
What did Yuon say, exactly?
Yuon thinks encountering Nalen, and finding a few relics, proves you're meant to find this Fount of Rajivari. It's baseless.
Perhaps the Force needed the right person for this task.
Maybe I'm just special.
There, Syo. Where there's blind certainty, there's arrogance. Yuon should know better.
First she welcomes that Trandoshan into the temple, now this? She's getting more unorthodox by the day.
What do you make of Yuon's claim, Padawan?
I trust in Master Yuon's wisdom.
I support her beliefs.
Master Yuon is my teacher. It isn't my place to question her.
It's not for me to judge.
Indeed not. That's the Council's responsibility.
I respect Master Yuon's beliefs, but I don't share them. My path is my own.
I think she's wrong.
The Council has agreed to accept Yuon's opinion. For now. But I am concerned about the dangers this path is leading you through.
Finding the Fount of Rajivari before Nalen Raloch does is important. But so is your safety, Padawan. Be mindful.
Go carefully, Padawan. Yuon is placing a lot of faith in you.
Ah, Padawan. I heard your shuttle arriving. I'm Master Syo Bakarn, of the Jedi Council. Welcome to Tython.
This is the ancestral home of our order, where the Jedi first came to be. And where our most promising Padawans complete their training.
I'm surprised a member of the Jedi Council would come to meet me.
Do you greet all new arrivals?
I wanted to meet the student who's caused such a stir.
The chance to see where the first Jedi walked, train where they trained--it's quite an honor.
I'm excited to be here.
So eager. You and your new Master should get along nicely.
With respect, Master Syo, I'd rather be training than talking.
Then I'd like to get started.
Your instructors tell me that even in childhood, you had a remarkable connection to the Force. We haven't seen such power in decades.
Your instructors say your understanding of Jedi lore and philosophy is unmatched. Such a powerful mind could make you a great Jedi.
Your instructors speak of your visions, that you walked the galaxy to find our order. We are honored to have you.
I was... hoping your new Master would be here. Yuon left her dig site and is returning to Tython specifically to train you.
Is Master Yuon an archaeologist?
A dig site?
In a way. As you become her Padawan, never forget your initial training, nor the Jedi Code:
It sounds like Master Yuon's putting a lot of faith in me. We haven't even met.
I hope I'm worthy.
Trust in your initial training. And never forget the Jedi Code:
If Master Yuon's so keen to train me, you'd think she'd show up on time.
And yet she's late.
A Jedi Master's time is rarely her own. Patience. Recall the Jedi Code:
"There is no emotion, there is peace. There is no ignorance, there is knowledge."
"There is no passion, there is serenity. There is no chaos, there is harmony. There is no death, there is the Force." This is....
Yuon. I was beginning to worry.
So you've arrived safely, my Padawan. I'm sorry I can't greet you properly, but we already have a crisis on our hands.
I'm at your service, Master.
I stand ready.
This crisis is the reason you were delayed.
That's why you were late.
Precisely.
I want to know what's happening.
What do you mean?
Tython is a treasure trove of ancient Jedi relics. Recently, our researchers uncovered several "teaching holograms," but they've not been fully studied.
These holograms may be records of the founders of the Jedi Order--they're absolutely irreplaceable.
But, a large group of Flesh Raiders has begun rampaging through that region. Those priceless holograms are in danger.
I've never heard of Flesh Raiders before.
Flesh Raiders?
Is there a way to protect the holograms?
Perhaps we can save them.
Someone must slip past the Flesh Raiders to recover these holograms' projectors. I intend this to be the first task of your training.
Whatever these "Flesh Raiders" are, they can't hurt something without physical form.
Why? They're holograms.
The Flesh Raiders are Tython's natives. Savage cannibals who destroy everything in their path.
Including the holograms' projectors. Combat teams are pushing the Flesh Raiders back, but retrieving the holograms is the first task of your training.
No. Yuon, you can't risk a Padawan against Flesh Raiders, even for such important artifacts.
A Padawan who was stronger in the Force at four years old, than I was at fifteen? Gifted students need greater challenges.
A Padawan who's studied every combat treatise of the last two centuries. Gifted students need greater challenges.
A Padawan who wandered alone for years--before learning Jedi techniques. Gifted students need greater challenges.
So I must recover these holograms, and watch for Flesh Raiders. Where should I begin?
I understand my task.
There's a difference between a challenge and risking your student's life.
I disagree. This is dangerous.
If Yuon believes you ready for a true test, you must be ready.
I was hoping you'd treat my abilities with the respect they deserve.
Good, you know my worth.
Pride is not a Jedi virtue, Padawan, nor is overconfidence.
The holograms are in the Gnarls. Be vigilant; that region has dangers of its own. If you encounter any difficulties, contact me on this holocommunicator.
When you have the holograms, meet me at the Jedi Temple. We have much to discuss.
A good day to you.
